title: Understanding Supplemental Security Income (SSI)-- SSI Benefits
author: ORDP; OISP
description: This page provides information on the maximum Federal benefit which changes yearly.
cleaned_text: SUPPLEMENTAL SECURITY INCOME (SSI) BENEFITS Generally, the maximum Federal SSI benefit amount changes yearly. SSI benefits increased in 2023 because there was an increase in the Consumer Price Index from the third quarter of 2021 to the third quarter of 2022. Effective January 1, 2023 the Federal benefit rate is $914 for an individual and $1,371 for a couple. Some States supplement the Federal SSI benefit with additional payments. This makes the total SSI benefit levels higher in those States. SSI benefit amounts and State supplemental payment amounts vary based upon your income, living arrangements, and other factors. NO STATE SUPPLEMENT The following States or territories do not pay a supplement to people who receive SSI: |Arizona ||Northern Mariana Islands | |Arkansas ||Tennessee | |Mississippi ||West Virginia | |North Dakota | SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTERED SUPPLEMENT Social Security administers the State supplement for the following States. You may contact us about your total benefit amount. |California ||Delaware* *Dual administration State. In these States, Social Security administers some categories of State supplement payments, while the State administers other categories of supplemental payments. STATE ADMINISTERED SUPPLEMENT The following States pay and administer their own supplemental payments and you may contact the State for payment information. |Alabama |See | See the publication titled, "SSI Recipient by State and County, 2020" on our website at [www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/statcomps/ssi_sc/](http://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/statcomps/ssi_sc/)
